name: TAP-34
sound: Tick sound when a key pressed
ports: keyboard, floppy drives, reader, modem, printer
description:
TAP 34 is a self design of Terta company from Hungary. Primarily it was designed as a terminal for big computer systems but it was also able to process data alone. The main integrated circuits were assembled in the USSR and in Hungary by Tungsram, but several parts were imported from other countries.

The built-in monitor was a DME-28 monochrome CRT made by Orion. This company    was famous for its televisions in Hungary and the other KGST countries.

The floppy drive attached to the computer was regular 8 inch 77 track drive using IBM format. This drive, which could use single and double sided disks, was a hungarian product also, made by the MOM.

The first design had some communications software in the EPROM, but at the end of the 80's the computer was redesigned. This second design had only 2 kBytes of EPROM, containing the bootloader software for the CP/M. The CPU card, the Ram card, the CRT card and the floppy controller card were all placed into a coloured plastic case.

The system was designed around the classic 8080 circuits.
- Display controller: i8275
- Floppy controller: i8271
- DMA: i8257
- i8255 PIO, i8253 CTC, i8251 USART

TAP-34 had the number EC-8534 in the EC-serries (united serries of computers) of East block and ex-USSR. Abbrevation "TAP" states for Teletype Abonents Point. There were three known modifications of EC-8534: original one, EC-8534.02, and EC-8534.3. The last one had optional capability to boot CP/M clone called VDOS.

The standard software included some built-in teletype programs and BASIC (Terta-BASIC). There was also a so called DP (Developer Package) floppy bootable system for assembly development (included editor, assembler and debugger).

Some constructive features of TAP-34 and the mentioned software suggest that there was some prototype CPU as well as original development software which were borrowed to design the TAP-34.
________

Contributors: Kun-Szabo Marton, Cyril Murzin
Source = www.machines.hu

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> F.D. UNIT ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>BBC floppy disc unit was delivered with a 8271 FD controller chip and a Filing System software in ROM to be fitted into the BBC system.<br> Two versions of F.D. units were available:<br>   - A single drive unit, single side, single density, 100 KB space.<br>   - A dual drive version, double side, double density, 800 KB space. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this a stupid advert ?!<br> Look carefully at each face !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gazelle was a huge computer compared to the personal computer sizes of the time, so large that it has casters on the cabinet for moving it!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dated december 1980</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Guizzi (http://www.scribd.com/doc/938905/Micro-Sistemas)</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>One found the same leaflet in various countries, translated in many languages.<br><br> Title was: 'Sirius 1, the professional computer to the power of 16' </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Olivetti M10, the portable professional micro-computer, here comes why."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Adopt a little gifted"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>The display says: "Personal computer Pravetz 82"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future....  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The facts speak for themselves. The QUAY 500 SERIES offers more for the money than North Star Horizon computers...<br><br> ...The bottom line is simple. There is a new star in the computer field. The 500 SERIES by Quay. It outshines all of the competition.<br><br></font>  A little pretentious tone!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Once upon a time, the future"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>First Newburry brochure cover<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
